Validation of the $10,000,000 accumulative effect of unearned state growth apportionment loss/2000-2006

Thursday, October 25th, 2007

FYI Source: Chancellors Office Recalculation Reports 2000/01 - 2005-06

Available State Growth Dollars Unearned Accumulative Effect

2000/01 $339,171 x 6 yrs = $2,035,026

2001/02 ……………………………-0-

2002/03 $600,650 x 4 yrs = $2,402,600

2003/04 $583,940 x 3 yrs = $1,751,820

2004/05 $492,320 x 2 yrs = $ 984,640

2005/06 $2,894,914 x 1 yr = $2,894,914

Total accumulative effect of growth apportionment loss………..$10,069,000 All Future Years

MSJC VP of Instruction takes Interim position at MiraCosta

Wednesday, October 24th, 2007

Dr. Pamela Deegan, VP of Instruction announced she will be leaving November 5th and has accepted an interim instructional position at MiraCosta College. Dr. Deegan was hired by former president Mark Zacovic and came to MSJC highly esteemed throughout the State of California for her administrative excellence. Under Dr. Deegan and the leadership of Dr. Mark Zacovic, college enrollments met and exceeded state growth targets. Thank you Dr. Pamela Deegan for your service to students at MSJC.

http://www.nctimes.com/articles/2007/05/07/news/californian/5607185434.txt/

NCTimes/May 6, 2007

MSJC administrator wins award

“Pamela Deegan, vice president of instruction at Mt. San Jacinto College was presented the Leadership Award for Administrative Excellence from the Association of California Community College Administrators at their annual meeting in March.

The award honors one administrator each year whose commitment to the profession stands out among peers, demonstrating creativity, innovation and commitment, according to the association.

Letters of nomination were submitted by administrators and faculty throughout the state who have worked with Deegan, who has worked in higher education for 31 years, the past 24 in the California Community College system. Prior to joining MSJC in August, she served six years as vice president of instruction at Miramar College in San Diego. She has also worked at Santiago Canyon College, Irvine Valley College and Cal State Los Angeles.

Last year, Deegan served as president of the California Community College Chief Instructional Officers, where she was instrumental in the formation of the state’s Basic Skills Initiative for Community Colleges, an initiative that is creating ways to assist students with English, math and other skills needed to succeed in college. Additionally, she served on the steering committee that formulated the state’s California Community College Strategic Plan.

Deegan serves on the executive board for the California Chief Instructional Officers, the steering committee for the Basic Skills Initiative, and the state chancellor’s budget work group which puts together the proposed budget for the California Community College system.”

“Space, retention key issues in race for MSJC board seats”/PE

Wednesday, October 24th, 2007

http://www.pe.com/localnews/temecula/stories/PE_News_Local_H_college24.3df9283.html#

The article written by Gail Wession of the PE, states two key issues pertinent to the upcoming board elections. How to better serve San Gorgonio Pass students & how to stop the flight of students to other community colleges. The answer to those issues is critical to the future of MSJC.

Blog:

In my opinion, the “flight of students to other community colleges” occurred during the administration of former president, Richard Giese, supported by Kadow and Sparkman, in which the college over six years left millions of available enrollment growth funds at the state table unearned having an accumulated negative annual budget loss of $10,000,000 for all future years. This administration cut fully funded class sections under Cap and then attributed the consequent loss of student enrollments to the fee increase.

Mr. Kadow and Joan Sparkman, led the charge in 2003 to rescind an aggressive enrollment growth policy that assured MSJC would at minimum meet annual growth targets (Cap) and would decide annually how far above the Cap the college could afford to grow without impeding operational general funds.

In 2006, these incumbents proposed the largest bond in the history of Riverside County, at which time, the college was in declining enrollment.

They continue to state that local bonds is the only way to grow our facilities. It’s not. The Menifee campus evidences otherwise. From 1990-2000 MSJC tripled state funded enrollments and doubled state funded facilities. Voters will continue to pass state bonds to fund facility growth as it has in past years.

It all about tax and spend with these incumbents.

Vote for Change. Vote Barker & Pedersen in this election.
